Award.AwardTitle: Using the World's Fastest Slipping Normal Fault to Understand the Mechanics of Low-angle Normal Faults
Award.AbstractNarration:
Normal faults play a major role in stretching the earth?s crust and generating earthquakes, yet their mechanics are poorly understood. Determining their strength, seismogenic potential, and why some may slip rapidly or accumulate large displacements are key to understanding not only rifted plate margins - with their associated mineral resources and earthquake hazard - but also basic fault mechanics. Rock deformation experiments predict that normal faults should initiate at steep dips of about 60-70ยบ and that they should frictionally lock up at dips less than 30-45ยบ. However, geologists have long observed major low-angle normal faults in the rock record. This observation and the lack of normal fault earthquakes with dips less than 30-45ยบ suggest that natural faults may be weaker than experiments indicate. Resolving this apparent mechanical paradox remains at the center of a debate about the strength of mature faults. To address the mysteries of slip on low-angle normal faults, this multi-disciplinary study of the best-exposed and fastest slipping of the few active examples known on Earth, the Mai'iu Fault in the Woodlark Rift of Papua New Guinea, uses GPS, thermochronometric, structural geologic and geomorphic observations, and modeling to test current ideas of low-angle fault mechanics. The project would advance desired societal outcomes through: (1) full participation of women in STEM; (2) increased public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology through outreach to Papua New Guinea native populations; (3) development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through the training of graduate students; and (4) increased partnerships through international collaboration with New Zealand scientists. The project is supported by the Tectonics Program and NSF's International Science and Engineering program.

As the world's fastest slipping active low-angle normal fault, the Mai'iu fault represents a world class opportunity to resolve controversies regarding the mechanics and evolution of low-angle normal faults. The Mai'iu Fault slips at 6-10 mm/year, and its smooth, domal surface is exposed in the landscape for more than 20 km, yielding a rare natural laboratory of an active and rapidly slipping low-angle normal fault in a continental rift. Through multidisciplinary data acquisition and modeling efforts, the University of Texas team in collaboration with New Zealand scientists will address the following hypotheses: (1) slip on low-angle normal faults can occur at cm/year rates on intrinsically weak planes; (2) slip on low-angle normal faults can occur by aseismic creep; (3) low-angle normal faults undergo temporal variations in slip rate; and (4) normal faults on the continents can acquire large displacements through the rolling hinge process. The research team employs: (1) campaign GPS to determine contemporary slip rates and whether or not the fault is creeping or locked; (2) geochronology and thermochronology ((U-Th)/He, fission track, multi-diffusion domain K-feldspar 40Ar/39Ar) to evaluate the evolution of low-angle normal faults, and variations in exhumation/slip rates through time; (3) cosmogenic radionuclide studies to evaluate Quaternary slip rates of the Mai'iu Fault; (4) structural geology to identify slip mechanisms on the fault and structural evolution of the dome; and (5) geodynamical modeling to integrate and interpret the various data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Normal faults are a type of faults that accommodates rifting or stretching apart of the Earth's crust.  These faults play a major role in extending the earth?s crust and generating earthquakes, yet how they operate is poorly understood. In particular, normal faults that dive beneath the earth at a shallow angle (less than 35 degrees or so) to the Earth's surface present a particular conundrum, because from what we know about rock and fault mechanics, these types of faults ("low-angle normal faults", or LANFs) should not exist. Despite this, LANFs are observed to accrue kilometers of displacement in many locations around the world.To understand how LANFs can accrue large amounts of slip, and to determine if they can generate earthquakes, we undertook a variety of geological and geophysical investigations on the best-exposed and fastest slipping LANF on Earth: the Mai'iu Fault in the Woodlark Rift of Papua New Guinea. Another major question that we set out to answer: can LANFs produce large earthquakes? This has important implications for earthquake hazard posed to regions with active LANFs.

Together with our New Zealand-based collaborators we are undertook a multidisciplinary field study of this unique setting using (1) GPS measurements to track modern-day land movement at a millimeter-per-year level, to determine how fast the Mai'iu fault is slipping, and whether or not the fault "locks-up" and to later slip in large earthquakes; (2) investigation of the geological record contained in the Mai'iu fault to resolve the evolution of LANFs, and how its movement may vary through time and space, (3) cosmogenic radioisotope studies to evaluate the slip rates of the Mai?iu Fault over the last 500,000 years (4) laboratory experiments on the Mai'iu fault rocks to determine whether or not such faults are capable of generating earthquakes. The observational studies were  integrated via computer modelling of LANF evolution and slip behavior. 

Three intensive field campaigns were undertaken for the geophysical and geological data acquisition (in 2015, 2016, and 2018).  For the  2018 field season, we also added a new component to investigate evidence for past seismic rupture of the Mai'iu fault using emerged coral reefs. 

Together, the GNSS data, geological data, rock deformation experimental results, and emerged coral data have revealed that the Mai'iu fault is indeed capable of producing large earthquakes (Mw ~6-7).  This is contrary to conventional wisdom that LANFs are extremely weak faults, and creep along steadily without producing earthquakes.  Together, results from our project show that the Mai'iu fault undergoes a spatially (and possibly temporally) variable range of slip behaviors, spanning from earthquakes through to creep events. The project also brought together diverse datasets and methods together to show that a "rolling-hinge" mechanism can explain LANF evolution, whereby the faults starts out with a steep angle at depth, and then rotates to a shallower angle closer to the Earth's surface.

Due to the high slip rate of the Mai'iu fault (~1 centimeter/year), the GPS network that we installed is arguably the first that is able to directly address questions regarding slip rate and seismic behavior on a LANF.  All other GPS networks spanning low-angle normal faults have been situated on very low slip rate faults (less than a few mm/yr) making it difficult to distinguish their slip behavior with GPS.  The cosmogenic radioisotope data also revealed very high slip rates (on the order of 1 cm/yr), consistent with our GPS measurements of modern-day movements.

New knowledge gained from this project has advanced understanding of the seismic and tsunami hazards posed by LANFs. We have found that portions of the Mai'iu fault are capable of hosting up to Magnitude 7.0 earthquakes.  This has implications for the tsunami hazard posed to coastal communities in the area by the offshore portion of the fault. The local people in the remote villages where we undertook our fieldwork have very little access to information about geohazards (such as earthquakes and tsunami). While doing fieldwork in PNG, we gave numerous lectures at the local schools, and often, to the entire village about our research. Locals were also employed to assist with GPS and geological fieldwork, as guides and carriers, and thus had first hand exposure to how scientific fieldwork is undertaken. 

The results of this NSF-funded project has enabled twelve peer-reviewed publications, and supported the thesis work of James Biemiller, who has recently been awarded is PhD at the University of Texas. The project also contributed to the work of two New Zealand-based PhD students (Marcel Mizera and Juergen Oesterle). Overall, the fast-slipping Mai?iu fault has offered a globally unique opportunity to resolve contemporary LANF slip behavior. The interdisciplinary nature of this project has enabled a comprehensive, multidisciplinary integration between geophysical, geological, and numerical modeling methods to gain a new understanding of the mechanics behind these enigmatic faults.
